title: 107_s1035
content: The "Great Lakes Preservation Act" may be cited as the official title of this legislation. The Act includes findings related to the Great Lakes. The Great Lakes are vital public natural resources that should be protected and managed for the benefit of all. They play a crucial role in the economies of the Great Lakes States and provide safe drinking water for millions of people. The Great Lakes Charter of 1985 guides the consultation process for water diversion in the basin. The Governors of the Great Lakes States and the Premiers of the Great Lakes Provinces base decisions on proposals to withdraw, divert, or use Great Lakes water on conservation and protection of water and natural resources in the basin. Decision-making regarding Great Lakes water should remain with the Governors of the Great Lakes States. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "Administrator" refers to the head of the EPA. "Bulk fresh water" is water extracted for transportation without further processing. "From the Great Lakes basin" includes water from specific lakes, interconnecting waterways, and tributaries. The curr_chunk provides definitions for terms related to the Great Lakes, including the definition of Great Lake, Great Lakes Province, and Great Lakes State. The Great Lakes are defined as Lake Erie, Lake Huron, Lake Michigan, Lake Ontario, and Lake Superior. The Great Lakes Province refers to Ontario or Quebec in Canada, while the Great Lakes State includes Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Minnesota, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, or Wisconsin. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary mentioned in the Act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Director of the National Park Service. SEC. 4. MORATORIUM ON EXPORT OF BULK FRESH WATER. Bulk fresh water from the Great Lakes basin shall not be exported from the United States. This moratorium will end when a Congress-approved mechanism for water decisions is in place. Congress suggests a US-Canada agreement to uphold the moratorium. SEC. 5. PRESERVATION OF HISTORIC GREAT LAKES LIGHTHOUSES. The Great Lakes have influenced settlement, commerce, and recreation. Lighthouses in the region are historically significant but are in poor condition. A study will be conducted to preserve them within 3 years. The Secretary will review programs and consult with various entities to preserve lighthouses in the Great Lakes States. Appropriations are authorized for this purpose.
